1. ctrl+click on a Sketch file and “Duplicate.”

1027898575987134464.text: I think I get most confused because the people who are saying they want a "ux/ui designer" most often are the ones who don't like that the designer pushes back on the whys or questions product decisions... it's like they *don't* want them designing a user experience.

1027883311476232192.text: A designer has a hard time making those artifacts if they don't know why someone is using the product or tool. They can make a lot of guesses, but in this industry we've seen where that gets you.

1027882827508006913.text: Maybe people think UX = wireframes? Interaction design? Prototyping? I'm not sure where the miscommunication is happening. But wireframes and mock-ups are artifacts of thinking, not ends in themselves.

1027833488807010304.text: My sincere wish is that people building protocols and discussing underlying architecture realize that they are making a user experience as well.

1027832900161548290.text: UI is the interface, also a *part* of UX. Not a binary.

1027832486582214656.text: But why does scalability matter? Could it be that if it doesn't, things won't work and it will be a poor experience and no one will use it/find value? User Experience is a whole thing, you can't really separate the mechanics from it.

1027832019936526336.text: I think there's a misconception about UX in our community. Lately I have heard people say "scalability" is the main barrier to adoption, and that "UX/UI" is also a small part.

1027513671637983233.text: What I have always loved about @brownorama's writing and advice is the inclusion of scripts/what to say. 1024270086641778688.text: We just need to normalize focusing on other people instead of looking inward when solving problems and building products. That includes developers especially. Inclusiveness pays off.

1024269567139438592.text: Designers of the future, in the face of increasing complexity and things like design systems, will need to become 1. Facilitators and 2. Systems thinkers as they help their team focus on users

1024269171826286592.text: It would be ridiculous, or at least extremely inefficient, to understand the problem, ideate, and iterate without the people building the thing in the room participating.

1024268832737841153.text: In the blockchain space especially, where things are super complex (and not just the code), no one person is a genius that understands everything. Teams have to know how to share info, critique ideas productively, and move forward together

1024268284135399429.text: One of the best things about design thinking is that it recognizes that a group must align to execute well and that everyone on a team has valuable insights

And for f*cks sake please stop equating visual design and making something pretty with "user experience".

Ok, love you all

1022091804030783490.text: I know it's hard. I believe in this community though or else I wouldn't be here. Read something on user experience, understand how to research your users, find low cost ways of prototyping before you code. Ask for help. Hire a designer and be partner to them.

1022090878398214146.text: I just get really riled up. Either admit you're making something for yourself or because you think the mechanics are cool, or I dunno, actually make something for someone else and truly consider what they need, and what they might be thinking, and if what you made works for them

1022089485364998144.text: And I am frustrated that we focus on "should we pay for gas" or "how to manage private keys" when the basics aren't even covered. Users aren't even getting that far for gas to become a thing because they don't even know why they should use your dapp in the first place

1022088633036275712.text: An interface is only part of it. CLI and emails and support are part of it. And guess what? There are people who are ~trained~ and have methods and tricks for making an experience good, methods for prioritizing the right thing to build, not just choosing the right color

1022087355711320064.text: And frankly, it's bordering on immoral to talk out of one side of your mouth and say "we want people to use our dapp! We want mass adoption!" and then invite them in and treat them like sh*t.

1022086789803245568.text: With a few exceptions, every single product in this space that I have used or had audited drops users off into these dead-ends and just leaves them there, floundering. People are not thinking through and testing *the entire experience*, considering what someone is trying to do

1022085954516000768.text: And that means *designing* with intent, having empathy, being humble, and realizing that just because we understand how a product or tool is to be used, the person we are making something for most likely won't on our first try

1022085339572305920.text:
But if we're going to reach any sort of adoption, we have to make things for people that ~are not us~

We have to understand other people and ask them questions and test our ideas with them

1022084822188142593.text: It's fine if you are buidl-ing something for yourself, because you know what you need and you will know if it solves the problem. Maybe other people are similar to you too, and they need what you're making

1022084317198123008.text: You know what though, I'm not done with this, because it blows my mind every single time. We focus so much on gas and private keys problems when talking about UX in this space, but like, we're not even doing the basics

1022080841806241793.text: The amount of people in the replies who think user experience == UI is making me sad y'all. Get rested and hydrated, we have so far to gohttps://twitter.com/APompliano/status/1021873662297862144 …
